discussion.content: can someone put answers in RIGHT order......
Thank you for this question.

comments.content: The keyword is «... external websites ...» that makes difference.

discussion.content:
> "Organization that has migrated their highly customized external websites into the cloud"

What makes this a public cloud, instead of a private cloud?

Marketing organization that outsources email
delivery to an online provider

Is email delivery really a public cloud? Unlike a website, the email app is only accessible internally. 

> "Organization that has migrated their highly
customized external websites into the cloud"

What makes this PaaS? I suppose we could *assume* this cloud provider provides a database, and a web server, but that is not specifically stated in the question.

questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP -
Drag and drop the cloud deployment model to the associated use-case scenario. Options may be used only once or not at all.
Select and Place:
//IMG//

choices.B: Comptia.org is running an older mail server, which may be vulnerable to exploits
choices.D: 192.168.102.67 is a backup mail server that may be more vulnerable to attack
choices.C: The DNS SPF records have not been updated for Comptia.org
choices.A: The public/private views on the Comptia.org DNS servers are misconfigured

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
"Public DNS zones MUST NOT contain [RFC 1918] addresses, IPv6 link-local or site-local addresses, or any other addresses designated by IANA as private, in any resource records where the context makes them appear to be globally-meaningful addresses."

https://www.ietf.org/proceedings/55/I-D/draft-ietf-dnsop-dontpublish-unreachable-03.txt

Is there any reason to think the backup server is more vulnerable? If so, why? If the backup server is more vulnerable because it uses a local address, then would that indicate that A is the correct answer?

It can't be A as the first IP address 198.X.X.X is the IP address of the local server. The following lines with the 10 and the 20 are from Comptia.org. 20 means the mail exchange there is a backup, so D is the correct answer.

comments.content:
"198.X.X.X is the IP address of the local server."
I am not sure what you mean. Do you mean the address at the coffee shop? 198.51.100.45?

discussion.content: According to some other dumps, D is the correct answer.

guys, this is a tough one!!! It says coffee shop and public internet. If I am in a company the private address might make sense, but not in public. 

Maybe the moderators can help?

all wrong - I take it back. its just a missing zone entry.
google says that in case of two mx entries the one with the higher number is a backup server.

So its D

comments.content:
The "Server: Unknown" refers to the DNS server that was queried by the nslookup command.
Do this command on your own machine towards nowhere.com and you'll see that the server and address at the top of the response is your own DNS server.

discussion.content: I had this question already in sec+ and I always look for hints in the wording when I sit for an comptia exam. The hint for me is "Server: Unknown". That suggests that this is not a modern server as it can not handle the request correct.

FWIW:
# nslookup -querytype=MX comptia.org
Server: 75.75.75.75
Address: 75.75.75.75#53

Non-authoritative answer:
comptia.org mail exchanger = 10 comptia-org.mail.protection.outlook.com.

Authoritative answers can be found from:

comments.content:
# nslookup comptia-org.mail.protection.outlook.com
Server: 75.75.75.75
Address: 75.75.75.75#53

Non-authoritative answer:
Name: comptia-org.mail.protection.outlook.com
Address: 104.47.36.36
Name: comptia-org.mail.protection.outlook.com
Address: 104.47.56.110

discussion.content: I agree with A. No reason a private address should be public ally viewable.
Correct Answer is A.

comments.content: How did you come to this conclusion? I would lean towards A. Since it is a private address, why would you include a private address in a public DNS record

discussion.content: D. This is also in the Sce+ exam and makes the most sense
It's not B. We can't discern the mail server version from this information.

questions.question_text:
Ann, a member of the finance department at a large corporation, has submitted a suspicious email she received to the information security team. The team was not expecting an email from Ann, and it contains a PDF file inside a ZIP compressed archive. The information security team is not sure which files were opened. A security team member uses an air-gapped PC to open the ZIP and PDF, and it appears to be a social engineering attempt to deliver an exploit.
Which of the following would provide greater insight on the potential impact of this attempted attack?

discussion.content: The pdf file could hide an executable file inside it using alternate data streams if the file system used is NTFS: https://owasp.org/www-community/attacks/Windows_alternate_data_stream
Both b and c are correct answers. But if you are successful reverse engineering you will get the most info about the malware.

comments.content: You reverse engineer malware applications, not documents. Reverse engineer a document makes no sense.
if there is a macro inside a word document then you need to reverse end in order to know how it works.

discussion.content: ANSWER IS C

C
If the suspicion is this is a social engineering attempt, all you can do is reverse engineer it and try to prevent your users from falling prey. If this looked like a virus or some kind of malware, you'd have options like A or B. Since it's a social engineering attempt, only C makes sense.

Is the PDF malware? Or does the PDF just instruct you to go to some other site? The question claims it *is* a PDF, not just appears to be a PDF. According to the question, the team does not know what files were opened. Maybe some other file ran when the zip folder was opened?

comments.content: the only problem with that is if you don't open the zip/pdf file, there is no active threat, just potential and you cannot reverse engineer a potential threat. from the question, the security team is using an air-gapped pc, which has no ports to the external network...

it's a physical sandbox. the only way to introduce data is via a thumb-drive. once the file is open on the air-gapped pc, then you can step back and run a protocol analyzer to see what the malware does

Is there any malware? It seems like there is only a document. This is a social engineering attack, not a malware attack. Usually these type of attacks instruct the user to go to some phishing site where a key logger will steal their password.

discussion.content: C is the correct answer. The only way to understand the true impact is to reverse engineer the malware.

comments.content: This might make sense. A PDF file is not executable, it is just data. What is the point of reverse engineering a data file? The PDF file is not meant to run some executable, it just instructs the recipient to go to some website, or something. This is a social engineering attack, not a malware attack.

discussion.content: D. Analyze network logs for unusual traffic.

choices.D: Analyze network logs for unusual traffic.
choices.B: Use a protocol analyzer on the air-gapped PC.
choices.C: Perform reverse engineering on the document.
choices.A: Run an antivirus scan on the finance PC.
choices.E: Run a baseline analyzer against the user's computer.

discussion.content:
Going with B. SCAP scanner and E. Network Enumerator.

"A network enumerator is used to scan the network and gain detailed information about users, groups, share drives, services and other things that may be visible on the enterprise network." - Jason Dion in his LinkedIn Learning course "CASP+ Cert Prep: 3 Enterprise Security Operations"
Has anyone taken CAS-003 yet with this dump?

Given a choice between SCAP scanner, and password cracker: I choose SCAP scanner.
1. The SCAP will tell me if I have strong password enforcement. That is all I need to know. If strong passwords are enforced, I can assume the passwords are strong. This is much easier than trying to crack every password.
2. I don't know if I want somebody going around cracking all the passwords. I'm not saying I trust you, and I'm not saying I don't; but I don't.
3. Even if I fix the weak passwords, how do I know that weak passwords won't be used again at some future date? It makes more sense to just check the policies.

comments.content: D1960 did you use these questions for your exam? How did it go?

Sure about E ?
As qwertybob pointed out: network enumeration can discover services. Password do not need to be shown to enforce strong password policies. Again, as qwertybob pointed out: SCAP can enforce strong passwords.

discussion.content:
A - Can't be correct because this tests programs for buffer overflows
B - This is one of the correct answers as it scan the system to see if it's hardened
C - Can't be correct because this doesn't satisfy the second requirement.
D - Possibly correct because an audit is performed at that particular moment. A cracker would test all current system and user accounts' credentials.
E - Can't be this one because an enumerator would only show the usernames and not their passwords.
F - Possibly correct if the logs from group policy violations are set to aggregate to the SIEM.

I'm kinda stumped on this kadoodle, but I think they are looking for B and D here.

B/F
I think the given answer is correct. I don't think the question is asking which 2 would be used in conjunction with each other, just which 2 could do the request action (service on/off, password complexity). Either SCAP or SIEM could do these action, although using both would be incredibly overkill. Every other answer could do one or the other, not both.

comments.content:
"Network enumeration is a computing activity in which usernames and info on groups, shares, and services of networked computers are retrieved."
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Network_enumeration

How would a siem provide that service? 

I think the answer has to be SCAP scanner and password cracker. Password cracking can help identify weak passwords, and SCAP can confirm we are complying with preset baselines. I leaned toward network enumerator, but I don’t like the phrasing. We would want to enumerate hosts, not networks.
I would say scap and network enumeration. SCAP can enforce strong password policies. And network enumeration can discover services.

discussion.content:
B. SCAP scanner
D. Password cracker

questions.question_text:
A new cluster of virtual servers has been set up in a lab environment and must be audited before being allowed on the production network. The security manager needs to ensure unnecessary services are disabled and all system accounts are using strong credentials.
Which of the following tools should be used? (Choose two.)

choices.A: Schedule weekly reviews of al unit test results with the entire development team and follow up between meetings with surprise code inspections.
choices.C: Enforce code quality and reuse standards into the requirements definition phase of the waterfall development process.
choices.D: Deploy an integrated software tool that builds and tests each portion of code committed by developers and provides feedback.
choices.B: Develop and implement a set of automated security tests to be installed on each development team leader's workstation.

discussion.content:
D is the definition of DevSecOps. "DevSecOps evolved to address the need to build in security continuously across the SDLC so that DevOps teams could deliver secure applications with speed and quality. Incorporating testing, triage, and risk mitigation earlier in the CI/CD workflow"

https://www.synopsys.com/glossary/what-is-devsecops.html
Software projects are usually Agile.

Selected Answer: D
I'm surprised there aren't more comments contesting the provided answer. I agree, D (below) makes more sense to me.

D. Deploy an integrated software tool that builds and tests each portion of code committed by developers and provides feedback.
Waterfall development process? I am not sure that is widely used anymore.

Maybe: D. Deploy an integrated software tool that builds and tests each portion of code committed by developers and provides feedback?
This will test code during the development process, instead of having the developers "blocked by a large number of security requirements applied at specific schedule points?"

questions.question_text:
A security engineer is embedded with a development team to ensure security is built into products being developed. The security engineer wants to ensure developers are not blocked by a large number of security requirements applied at specific schedule points.
Which of the following solutions BEST meets the engineer's goal?
